guidelines.title: Evidence-based mentor training emphasizing communication and inclusion
guidelines.content: Effective mentorship requires structured training focused on communication skills, aligning expectations between mentor and mentee, and promoting equity and inclusion. Mentors should receive formal training rather than relying solely on intuition.
guidelines.source: Introduction to Effective Mentorship for Early-Career Scientists (Pfund et al., 2021)

guidelines.title: Mentors as role models with structured goal-setting
guidelines.content: Mentors should serve as role models for research excellence while implementing structured goal-setting processes. This is particularly important when mentoring high school students or early-career researchers who need clear direction and examples to follow.
guidelines.source: Ten Simple Rules for Providing a Meaningful Research Experience to High School Students (Lescak et al., 2019)

guidelines.title: NIH-funded mentoring resources and curriculum
guidelines.content: The National Research Mentoring Network provides evidence-based resources and training curricula, particularly the widely-used 'Entering Mentoring' curriculum. These resources offer structured approaches to mentorship development.
guidelines.source: National Research Mentoring Network (NRMN, 2014-ongoing)

guidelines.title: Evidence-based mentor training curricula and evaluation
guidelines.content: Mentorship effectiveness can be improved through evidence-based training curricula and proper evaluation tools. CIMER provides structured approaches to both training mentors and assessing mentoring relationship outcomes.
guidelines.source: Center for the Improvement of Mentored Experiences in Research (CIMER)

guidelines.title: Consensus recommendations for effective mentorship in STEMM
guidelines.content: Evidence-based consensus recommendations include frameworks for mentor training, institutional support systems, assessment metrics, and scalable mentoring programs. These provide comprehensive guidance for building mentorship programs.
guidelines.source: The Science of Effective Mentorship in STEMM (2019)

guidelines.title: Defining measurable mentoring relationship attributes
guidelines.content: Effective mentoring relationships have specific, measurable attributes and outcomes. Use validated instruments to evaluate mentoring relationships and track progress, particularly useful for program evaluation and improvement.
guidelines.source: Defining Attributes and Metrics of Effective Research Mentoring Relationships (2016)

guidelines.title: Training scientists to be better leaders
guidelines.content: Formal leadership and mentoring training for PIs transforms mentorship quality in STEM. Provide concrete examples and track outcomes to demonstrate the value of structured leadership development programs.
guidelines.source: Transforming mentorship in STEM by training scientists to be better leaders (2018)

guidelines.title: Practical mentoring practices for early-career scientists
guidelines.content: Early-career researchers benefit from practical, concrete mentoring practices derived from 'Entering Mentoring' workshops. Focus on actionable strategies rather than abstract principles when guiding new researchers.
guidelines.source: Introduction to effective mentorship for early-career research scientists (2021)

guidelines.title: Characteristics of successful vs failed mentoring relationships
guidelines.content: Successful mentoring relationships are characterized by reciprocity and clear expectations. Common failure modes include unclear expectations, lack of communication, and absence of mutual respect. Address these proactively.
guidelines.source: Characteristics of Successful and Failed Mentoring Relationships (2014)

guidelines.title: Ten evidence-based undergraduate research mentoring practices
guidelines.content: Ten salient practices for undergraduate research mentoring are applicable across disciplines. These evidence-based practices provide concrete guidance for mentoring undergraduate researchers effectively.
guidelines.source: Ten Salient Practices of Undergraduate Research Mentors (2015)

guidelines.title: Mentoring practices predictive of doctoral success
guidelines.content: Specific mentoring behaviors predict doctoral persistence and productivity. Use these empirically-identified behaviors when designing doctoral mentoring interventions and tracking student progress.
guidelines.source: Mentoring practices predictive of doctoral outcomes (2023)

guidelines.title: Prioritizing mentorship as scientific leaders
guidelines.content: Scientific leaders and departments should institutionalize mentorship priorities through concrete actions and policies. Provide actionable guidance for integrating mentorship into institutional culture.
guidelines.source: Prioritizing Mentorship as Scientific Leaders (2024)

guidelines.title: Mentee strategies for building mentor interactions
guidelines.content: While focused on mentee strategies, this highlights mentor responsibilities including providing access, giving feedback, and facilitating network connections. Ensure mentors understand their role in supporting mentee development.
guidelines.source: Building and sustaining mentor interactions as a mentee (2021)

guidelines.title: Institutional recommendations for sustained mentorship excellence
guidelines.content: Departments, institutions, and funders should implement specific recommendations to ensure sustained excellence in academic mentorship. Focus on systemic changes rather than individual improvements alone.
guidelines.source: Improving academic mentorship practices (2024)

guidelines.title: Disciplined research habits emphasizing depth over breadth
guidelines.content: Effective research requires disciplined habits, clear vision, and prioritizing depth over breadth. Develop systematic approaches to research rather than pursuing scattered interests.
guidelines.source: Principles of Effective Research (Michael Nielsen, 2004)

guidelines.title: Tackling important problems while tolerating ambiguity
guidelines.content: Focus research efforts on tackling genuinely important problems while developing tolerance for ambiguity and uncertainty. Don't avoid difficult questions simply because they lack clear solutions.
guidelines.source: Ten Simple Rules for Doing Your Best Research (Erren & Erren, 2007)

guidelines.title: ML paper writing with narrative clarity and evidence
guidelines.content: ML papers should prioritize narrative clarity, high-quality evidence, and iterative writing processes. Focus on telling a clear story backed by rigorous evidence rather than just presenting results.
guidelines.source: Highly Opinionated Advice on How to Write ML Papers (Neel Nanda, 2025)

guidelines.title: Hands-on mechanistic interpretability curriculum
guidelines.content: Mechanistic interpretability research benefits from hands-on curriculum emphasizing coding and experiments. Practical experience with tools and methods is essential for developing research skills.
guidelines.source: Mechanistic Interpretability: Getting Started (Neel Nanda, 2024)

guidelines.title: Systematic ML research process
guidelines.content: Use a systematic process for ML research: problem definition, establishing baselines, and iterative experimentation. Structure prevents wandering and ensures progress toward meaningful results.
guidelines.source: Framing Machine Learning Research (TrendSpider blog, 2023)

guidelines.title: Research practice checklist for transparency
guidelines.content: Follow a compact, actionable checklist covering transparency, data sharing, preregistration, and sound statistics. This provides an easy framework for mentors to teach and reinforce good research practices.
guidelines.source: Ten simple rules for good research practice (2022)

guidelines.title: Defining research rigor with practical lab practices
guidelines.content: Research rigor involves redundant design, error recognition, and logical thinking. Implement practical lab and analysis practices that emphasize these elements in daily research work.
guidelines.source: Rigorous Science: a How-To Guide (2016)

guidelines.title: Common methodological mistakes and mitigation
guidelines.content: Catalogues frequent design, analysis, and reporting errors with mitigation strategies. Mentors should emphasize these common pitfalls during supervision to prevent methodological mistakes.
guidelines.source: Common methodological mistakes (2023)

guidelines.title: Practical guidelines for evaluating research quality
guidelines.content: Use practical guidelines to evaluate research quality and avoid common biases. This serves as a useful mentoring tool for teaching critical review skills and quality assessment.
guidelines.source: Evaluating Research Quality (2019)

guidelines.title: Four-dimensional research quality framework
guidelines.content: Evaluate research using four dimensions: technical content, structural coherence, writing precision, and ethical integrity. Use this as a manuscript preparation checklist.
guidelines.source: Enhancing Research Methodology and Academic Publishing (2023)

guidelines.title: Rigorous empirical methods for identifying best practices
guidelines.content: Use rigorous empirical methods to identify best practices in applied research. This methodological guide helps mentors guide students conducting applied research studies.
guidelines.source: Best practices research: methodological guide (2005)

guidelines.title: Developing research taste through problem selection
guidelines.content: Research taste involves intuition for problem choice and selection. Develop this through understanding what makes problems worth pursuing and cultivating intuition through mentorship and experience.
guidelines.source: My Research Process: Understanding and Cultivating Research Taste (Neel Nanda, 2025)

guidelines.title: Synthesis of brute-force and calculation-heavy approaches
guidelines.content: Effective problem solving combines Edison's brute-force experimentation with Tesla's calculation-heavy theoretical approach. Recommend synthesis rather than exclusively favoring one method.
guidelines.source: Edison vs. Tesla: Approaches to Problem Solving (Scott Berkun, 2007)

guidelines.title: Stepwise AI research roadmap
guidelines.content: Follow a stepwise roadmap for AI research: build foundations, read papers systematically, reproduce key results, then conduct original experiments. This provides structure for new researchers.
guidelines.source: How to Do Research in AI: A Beginner's Guide (Rohansoni, 2025)

guidelines.title: Expert problem-solving model with teachable subskills
guidelines.content: Expert problem solving in science and engineering follows an empirically-derived model with teachable subskills. Use this for mentor training in reasoning skills and problem-solving assessment.
guidelines.source: A Detailed Characterization of the Expert Problem-Solving Process in S&E (2021)

guidelines.title: Cognitive science foundations for problem-solving instruction
guidelines.content: Instructional strategies should be based on cognitive science foundations including metacognition and knowledge organization. Mentors can adapt these interventions for research training.
guidelines.source: Instructional Strategies that Foster Effective Problem-Solving (2023)

guidelines.title: Translating problem-solving into practice
guidelines.content: Bridge the gap between theoretical problem-solving approaches and practical implementation. Use reflective questions and practical prompts that mentors can employ in real situations.
guidelines.source: The art of problem solving and its translation into practice (2022)

guidelines.title: Attentional engagement predicts problem-solving strategies
guidelines.content: Attentional engagement and micro-strategies are linked to effective problem solving. Mentors should coach focus and iterative strategies to improve problem-solving outcomes.
guidelines.source: Microfoundations of Problem Solving: Attentional Engagement Predicts Strategies (2020)

guidelines.title: Structured inventive problem-solving with computational aids
guidelines.content: TRIZ (structured inventive problem-solving) can be augmented with computational tools like LLMs. Mentors should introduce systematic creative methods and show how to use computational aids effectively.
guidelines.source: TRIZ-GPT: An LLM-augmented method for problem-solving (2024)

guidelines.title: Active learning strategies for critical thinking development
guidelines.content: Use questioning techniques, written exercises, debates, and discussion methods to promote critical thinking. These strategies can be adapted for research meetings and journal clubs.
guidelines.source: Active Learning Strategies to Promote Critical Thinking (Paul et al., 2003)

guidelines.title: Structured planning tool for critical thinking
guidelines.content: Use structured planning tools with demonstrated effectiveness for developing critical thinking. Require students to use these tools for project planning and reflection.
guidelines.source: Enabling critical thinking development through a structured planning tool (Golden, 2023)

guidelines.title: Integrated approach combining writing, dialogue, and group work
guidelines.content: Combine writing assignments, Socratic dialogue, and group work to improve students' argumentation skills. This integrated approach is adaptable to research training contexts.
guidelines.source: Cultivating Critical Thinking Skills: Integrated Cogency Method (ICM) (2024)

guidelines.title: Assessment strategies for critical thinking development
guidelines.content: Implement practical assessment strategies and course designs for deliberate critical thinking development. Structure supervisory training to emphasize reasoning and decision-making skills.
guidelines.source: Strategy for development and assessment of critical thinking in undergraduate management & leadership (Zapalska et al., 2020)

guidelines.title: Research process: explore, understand, distill
guidelines.content: Structure research thinking around exploration, understanding, and distillation phases. Emphasize feedback loops, reflection, and the role of mentorship in developing critical thinking.
guidelines.source: How I Think About My Research Process: Explore, Understand, Distill (Neel Nanda, 2025)

guidelines.title: Focus on research program over individual papers
guidelines.content: The most important aspect of research is choice of your research program: inter-related areas to focus on. Choose something unique that wouldn't happen if you don't do it to avoid chasing trends.
guidelines.source: TLDR: Tips on Doing Good AI Research

guidelines.title: Research for curiosity, not publications
guidelines.content: Don't do research for writing papers; do it for curiosity. Decouple research and artifacts: publish when you have novel concrete learning; use blogs/tweets for rediscoveries or negative results.
guidelines.source: TLDR: Tips on Doing Good AI Research

guidelines.title: Research artifacts should build peer intuition
guidelines.content: Research artifacts build intuition for peers: back claims with concrete evidence. Focus on helping others understand rather than just demonstrating results.
guidelines.source: TLDR: Tips on Doing Good AI Research

guidelines.title: Work in problem-defined fields, not method-defined ones
guidelines.content: Work in a field defined by problems and principles, not methods, because methods churn out while fundamental problems persist. Focus on enduring challenges rather than trending techniques.
guidelines.source: Omar Khattab: Tips

guidelines.title: Invest in projects, not papers
guidelines.content: Think of larger vision/sub-area/paradigm to lead. Make project repos for cohesive thinking. Select timely problems with large headroom (2x-10x improvement) and fanout (impact on downstream applications).
guidelines.source: On Impactful AI Research (okhat/blog)

guidelines.title: Think two steps ahead in research
guidelines.content: Avoid low-hanging fruit and anticipate blocks in obvious paths. Consider what obstacles others will encounter and position your work to address those future challenges.
guidelines.source: On Impactful AI Research (okhat/blog)

guidelines.title: Iterate fast with academic-scale problems
guidelines.content: Get quick feedback by working on academic-scale problems that allow rapid iteration. Popularize your work by making it known before publication and continue investing in successful directions.
guidelines.source: On Impactful AI Research (okhat/blog)

guidelines.title: Treat research as a startup product
guidelines.content: Understand user problems and funnel excitement. Like a product, research should solve real problems and generate enthusiasm in the community.
guidelines.source: On Impactful AI Research (okhat/blog)

guidelines.title: Build a coherent research program
guidelines.content: Need a research program for career success: projects toward larger question. Work on far-out, non-interchangeable ideas. Some work takes 1-2 years to establish the problem itself.
guidelines.source: HN Discussion

guidelines.title: PhD focuses on navigating problems, not solutions
guidelines.content: PhD is about spotting and navigating problems, not solutions. Collaboration is key to success. Impact comes via leaps (industry scale) or influencing thought processes.
guidelines.source: HN Discussion

guidelines.title: Focus on uniqueness and avoid incremental work
guidelines.content: Ask: What won't exist/popularize without you? Avoid incremental work - leave that to AIs as it's easy to automate. Focus on work that requires human insight and creativity.
guidelines.source: HN Discussion

guidelines.title: Papers motivate through feedback and build discipline
guidelines.content: It's OK to publish without perfect projects; papers motivate via feedback. Finishing papers builds discipline and communication skills essential for research careers.
guidelines.source: HN Discussion

guidelines.title: Break projects into expertise-based components
guidelines.content: Break projects into components and collaborate by expertise. Scope missing parts and recruit appropriate collaborators. This ensures higher quality outcomes than trying to do everything alone.
guidelines.source: On Collaborating (Minh Nhat Nguyen)

guidelines.title: Structured collaboration stages
guidelines.content: Collaboration stages: Idea (juniors), Methods/dataset (juniors), Early experiments (juniors), Scaled experiments (seniors for feedback), Review (seniors), Writing/publishing (mixed). Match expertise to task complexity.
guidelines.source: On Collaborating (Minh Nhat Nguyen)

guidelines.title: Co-author with publication experience
guidelines.content: Co-author with those who have publication experience (lead/last author at top conferences). Promote research as product: useful, interesting, and well-known.
guidelines.source: On Collaborating (Minh Nhat Nguyen)

guidelines.title: Three-stage research process
guidelines.content: Research stages: Ideation (choose problem), Exploration (maximize info per time through intuition, curiosity, gears-level questions), Understanding (form hypotheses with evidence for/against, maintain skepticism, design good experiments), Distillation (compress claims, gather rigorous evidence, write early).
guidelines.source: Neel Nanda: Research Process (Explore, Understand, Distill)

guidelines.title: Prioritize truth-seeking over exciting papers
guidelines.content: Goal is to find truth, not write exciting papers. Research is hard; take breaks for productivity. Maintain focus on genuine discovery rather than publication pressure.
guidelines.source: Neel Nanda: Research Process (Explore, Understand, Distill)

guidelines.title: Truth-seeking mindset
guidelines.content: Be skeptical of world and claims; don't attach to ideas. Maintain intellectual humility and willingness to abandon hypotheses when evidence contradicts them.
guidelines.source: Neel Nanda: Key Mindsets

guidelines.title: Ruthless prioritization
guidelines.content: Prioritize ruthlessly due to finite time. Focus on high-impact activities and eliminate inefficiencies. Time is the most constrained resource in research.
guidelines.source: Neel Nanda: Key Mindsets

guidelines.title: Move fast and eliminate inefficiency
guidelines.content: Create tight feedback loops, use good tooling, and run subset experiments first. Speed of iteration often matters more than perfection of individual experiments.
guidelines.source: Neel Nanda: Key Mindsets

guidelines.title: Cultivate research taste through analysis
guidelines.content: Research taste involves problem selection and intuitions. Develop by dissecting admired papers (including flawed ones) and making predictions in your field. Right predictions build intuition.
guidelines.source: Neel Nanda: Cultivating Research Taste

guidelines.title: Papers as evidence-backed narratives
guidelines.content: Papers are evidence-backed narratives to build peer intuition. Core elements: 1-3 novel claims, rigorous evidence, proper motivation/background. Write when insights are legible and meaningful.
guidelines.source: Neel Nanda: Writing ML Papers

guidelines.title: Establish novelty through literature review
guidelines.content: Establish novelty via thorough literature review that expands knowledge. Convince readers with strong baselines and quality evidence over quantity.
guidelines.source: Neel Nanda: Writing ML Papers

guidelines.title: Iterative writing process
guidelines.content: Write iteratively: Abstract → outline → intro → draft. Focus on abstract, intro, and figures since many readers are skimmers. Prioritize being informative and precise.
guidelines.source: Neel Nanda: Writing ML Papers

guidelines.title: Effective paper introduction structure
guidelines.content: Intro should motivate novelty and importance narrowly with 1-3 clear claims. Related work should explain differences and contrast previous attempts.
guidelines.source: How to Write an Okay Research Paper (YouTube)

guidelines.title: Methods and experiments sections
guidelines.content: Background: provide relevant knowledge with minimal notation. Methods: go from high to low level with algorithm/pseudocode, explain to your past self. Experiments: anticipate from context and present results that support claims.
guidelines.source: How to Write an Okay Research Paper (YouTube)

guidelines.title: Support claims with standalone analysis
guidelines.content: Support all claims with evidence. Make tables standalone and include analysis covering robustness, ablations, and qualitative insights.
guidelines.source: How to Write an Okay Research Paper (YouTube)

guidelines.title: Page 1 determines acceptance
guidelines.content: Page 1 determines acceptance: title, abstract, figure 1, intro should be specific, memorable, valuable, and hook readers. The rest avoids rejection through proper figures/tables, ablations, baselines, stats, and human evaluation.
guidelines.source: How to Get Your Paper Accepted (Maxwell Forbes)

guidelines.title: Design for skimmers
guidelines.content: Many readers are skimmers who focus on figures, tables, and conclusions. Include examples, graphics, and takeaways in captions. Conclusion should summarize abstract/intro and explain what was achieved and why it matters.
guidelines.source: How to Get Your Paper Accepted (Maxwell Forbes)

guidelines.title: Isolate research questions, avoid full systems
guidelines.content: Research should isolate and answer one thing clearly. Products require end-to-end work (millions of engineering hours). Avoid building full systems in research - focus on specific insights.
guidelines.source: Don't Make Things Actually Work (Maxwell Forbes)

guidelines.title: Focus on doing good science
guidelines.content: Science problems are easy to find but hard to solve. Science is fundamentally social and about communication. Focus on doing good science rather than trying to reform the entire system.
guidelines.source: Don't Try to Reform Science (Maxwell Forbes)

guidelines.title: Papers as advertisements for ideas
guidelines.content: Papers serve as research currency for conferences and advertisements for ideas. Structure around central narrative (the idea's story, not yours). Requires more work for effective pitch including ablations.
guidelines.source: Your Paper Is an Ad (Maxwell Forbes)

guidelines.title: Recognition through memorable positioning
guidelines.content: For professors: navigate busy idea space and appease reviewers. Recognition comes from sticking in heads through brand marketing. Consider: what are you known for?
guidelines.source: Your Paper Is an Ad (Maxwell Forbes)
